docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''For Lost Pregnancies, New Rites of Mourning'' (front page, Jan. 25): The pendulum may have swung from underacknowledging pregnancy losses to overritualizing them. When I had a stillbirth a few months ago, the hospital staff pressured my husband and me to hold and name the baby and take home mementos that included photographs, footprints and a lock of hair. We instead chose simply to bury our baby in a private religious ceremony. We felt that it would be too painful to see or hold the baby and that doing so would make moving forward that much harder. The staff was reluctant to accept our wishes, and we were made to feel that we were not mourning properly.
docs.abstract: Sarah Klagsbrun letter on Jan 25 article on mourning rites for lost pregnancies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Caught between the doctrine of their church and the laws of their land, Germany's Roman Catholic bishops bowed to the wishes of Pope John Paul II today and agreed to withhold counseling certificates that play a central part in this country's legal procedures for abortion. The decision, announced by Bishop Karl Lehmann of Mainz, followed an ecclesiastical and political debate over a letter to the bishops from the Pope sent shortly before his visit to Cuba.

headline.main: Obeying Pope, German Bishops End Role in Abortion System

docs.abstract: Germany's Roman Catholic bishops bow to wishes of Pope John Paul II and agree to withhold counseling certificates that play key role in nation's legal procedures for abortion; aides say Chancellor Helmut Kohl, practicing Catholic, remains committed to abortion procedures; technically, abortion is illegal in Germay, but pregnancies may be terminated within first 12 weeks with counseling certificate; organizations linked to Catholic Church run 264 of Germany's 1,685 abortion counseling centers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Congressional Republicans Supporting Clinton on Iraq The Republican leadership in Congress lined up behind President Clinton's stance on Iraq, saying that the sex scandal absorbing the White House should not be allowed to affect the way the United States responds to a foreign policy problem. A1 The leader of the United Nations weapons inspection commission, Richard Butler, confirmed earlier reports that his team had evidence that Iraq has loaded biological weapons into missile warheads. docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Abortion's Children,'' Peggy Noonan's Jan. 22 Op-Ed article: Children faced with pregnancy who wait to make a decision about their condition until after their babies are born are more likely to come from homes in which issues concerning sex, abortion and the freedom of choice are avoided -- not aired, as Ms. Noonan suggests.

headline.main: Where Is Compassion in the Abortion Debate?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Peggy Noonan (Op-Ed, Jan. 22) blames recent cases of alleged infanticide on things young people hear about late-term abortion. I, however, blame it on what youths did not hear about -- family planning, the responsibility of both partners and adoption. Anti-abortion groups, which have repeatedly tried to eliminate sex education in schools, imply that late-term abortion is the only reproductive service available or performed. In fact, only 1 percent of abortions take place after the first 21 weeks of pregnancy.

headline.main: Where Is Compassion in the Abortion Debate?; Know All the Options

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR a pregnant woman who wants to know whether she is carrying a healthy fetus, the wait for medical tests can seem endless. The most common test for genetic disorders, amniocentesis, is usually not done until the 15th or 16th week of pregnancy, and it takes another week or two to get results. The test involves removing a sample of the fluid surrounding the fetus in the uterus to obtain fetal cells for genetic analysis. Doctors have tried to find ways to provide answers sooner. That would reassure most parents faster and lessen the pain for those who receive bad news by letting them consider abortion earlier in pregnancy, when it is physically and emotionally less traumatic.

headline.main: Research Finds Risk In Early Test of Fetus

docs.abstract: New study of 4,000 women in Canada finds that early amniocentesis, performed 11 or 12 weeks into pregnancy, led to large increase in risk of foot deformity similar to clubfoot as well as slight increase in chance of miscarriage or stillbirth; findings apply only to early amniocentesis, not to standard procedure, which is considered reliable and has very low rate of complications (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A robust economy and years of Government pressure have helped move minority groups closer to the mainstream. But when it comes to health, studies show a stubborn, daunting and in some respects growing disparity between black and white Americans. For decades, blacks have suffered higher death rates from nearly all major causes. Although life expectancy has increased for all groups, differences persist. And Government and academic research shows a widening gap between blacks and others in the incidences of asthma, diabetes, major infectious diseases and several forms of cancer.

headline.main: Health Gap Grows, With Black Americans Trailing Whites, Studies Say

docs.abstract: Studies show, that despite robust economy and years of Government pressure that has helped move minority groups closer to mainstream, there remains stubborn, daunting and in some respects growing disparity in health care between black and white Americans; charts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''My theory is that birth and death occurring on the same day, the confluence of life's greatest mysteries, was just too much for people to handle. But today, men and women, grieving mothers and fathers, are demanding that people accept their right to mourn, their need to mourn.'' REV. DR. SARAH L. FOGG, a Baptist minister who conducts memorial services for children lost in pregnancy. [34]
